iugum. This was an opening made in the Samnite lines, with two spears set upright, and a third passed over them. Arnold says it was no peculiar insult, but a common usage, like the modern ceremony of piling arms, to treat prisoners of war in such a way. Mommsen says, ‘The Samnite army, drunk with victory, could not resist the desire to subject their foes to the disgrace.’ But Pontius was so far from being cruel. that he granted sumpter-horses to carry the wounded to Rome'. It is just possible that he regarded such a ceremony as a political necessity, to show the completeness of the surrender, in the same way as the Germans, in 1870, regarded the occupatiori of part os Paris.
